metadata.author: Original NorCal Trail Game
metadata.description: A psychedelic journey from Boston to San Francisco in a VW bus during the 1960s counterculture movement

professions.description: You've got connections and cash, but the cops are watching you, man.
You left school to find yourself. More resourceful but haunted by doubt.
You see beauty everywhere but barely have two pennies to rub together.

early.text: You see a hitchhiker on the roadside. They flag you down. Do you pick them up?

choices.text: ğŸ’° Pick them up for cash
choices.message: 'Ass, Grass, or Gas - Nobody Rides for Free!' They hand you $25. Good deal, but kinda greedy, man.

choices.text: ğŸŒ¿ Pick them up for herbs
choices.message: 'Ass, Grass, or Gas!' They contribute to the herb collection! The vibes are EXCELLENT! âœŒï¸

choices.text: â›½ Pick them up for gas
choices.message: 'Ass, Grass, or Gas!' They pour 15 units of gas from their can into your tank. Far out!

choices.text: ğŸ†“ Give them a free ride
choices.message: You give them a free ride. Spread the love, man! They share cool stories and good vibes.
You drive past. They flip you off. Bad karma, dude.

early.text: ğŸ’¥ BREAKDOWN! Your VW bus sputters and dies on the side of the road! What do you do?

You use your spare parts and fix it quickly! Smart thinking!

early.text: ğŸª You stumble upon a small music festival in a field! Live bands, dancing, the whole scene! Sunshine's eyes light up: 'Can we STAY?!'

choices.message: You break out the guitar and JAM for hours! People share food! This is EVERYTHING! âœ¨ğŸ¸
You dance until your feet hurt! Worth every second! This is LIVING! ğŸŒˆ
You relax with some herbs, listen to the music, and soak it all in. Perfect vibes! â˜®ï¸
Everyone's bummed. 'We NEVER get to have fun!' Oof. Morale hit.

early.text: ğŸš¨ The fuzz pulls you over. 'Your taillight's out, hippie.'

choices.message: You hand over the cash. The cop smirks and drives off.
He's not interested in your philosophy. He writes you TWO tickets out of spite.

choices.message: You peel out. Your VW bus goes 0-60 in... never. He doesn't even bother chasing you. But now you're paranoid for 200 miles.
choices.failMessage: He catches you immediately. Your bus tops out at 40mph. Now you're getting arrested. This takes DAYS to sort out.

early.text: ğŸ½ï¸ Classic roadside diner! Chrome and neon! The waitress calls you 'hon.' Moonbeam is CHARMED.

early.text: ğŸŒ… Sunset over the plains. Sky goes orange, then pink, then purple. River whispers: 'Far out...' Nobody moves for 20 minutes.

choices.message: You set up the camera on the roof. Timer goes off. PERFECT sunset photo with everyone! This is going on the wall! ğŸ“·âœ¨

No photos. No words. Just experiencing it. When it's over, everyone exhales. Perfect moment. â˜®ï¸
Everyone gives you the LOOK. 'SERIOUSLY?!' You stop. Too late, sun's already set. Blew it.

early.text: ğŸ’¥ FLAT TIRE. Middle of nowhere. No shade. Stardust kicks the tire: 'Of COURSE.'

endings: You and your friends started a commune in the redwoods. Twenty years later, it's still thriving. People come from all over to learn about organic farming and free love. You never stopped believing. â˜®ï¸
The five of you became legends in Haight-Ashbury. Your bus is parked permanently on a corner, turned into a free coffee shop. Locals call you 'the originals.' The spirit lives on. ğŸŒ»
You founded a music collective that toured the country spreading peace. Your story inspired thousands to hit the road. Some say the journey never really ends. ğŸ¸

professionEndings.dealer: By the 80s, you'd opened a chain of 'organic wellness stores.' You don't talk about the old days much. The VW bus is in your garage, covered in dust. Sometimes you wonder what happened to the dream. ğŸ’¼
professionEndings.artist: Your 'authentic hippie experience' memoir became a bestseller in 1985. You do book tours in a suit. The irony isn't lost on you. The bus sold at auction for $50,000. ğŸ“š
professionEndings.dropout: You used the trip as a business school essay. MBA, corner office, stock options. The bus is long gone. Your kids think the old photos are Photoshopped. You don't tell them the truth. ğŸ¢

epilogues.template: You made it, but the others drifted away. You stayed in touch for a while - Christmas cards, the occasional phone call. But people change. You still have the photos, though. Sometimes that's enough. {{partySizeIcon}}

itemEndings.guitar: You never left San Francisco. Busking on street corners turned into coffee shop gigs, then small venues. You're not famous, but you're free. The bus is parked by the ocean. You play music every sunset. ğŸ¸
itemEndings.default: You documented the whole journey in sketches and paintings. A gallery in North Beach gave you your first show. Critics called it 'raw' and 'authentic.' You called it 'Tuesday.' Your art spoke what words couldn't. ğŸ¨

moraleEndings.high: Turns out, leaving college was the best decision you ever made. You went back eventually - on your own terms - to study environmental science. Now you teach. Your students call you 'the cool professor.' You still have the bus. ğŸŒ±
moraleEndings.low: You drifted for a few more years after San Francisco. Eventually found your way - just took longer than expected. Looking back, the journey taught you more than any classroom ever could. You don't regret a thing. ğŸ›¤ï¸

epilogues.ending: San Francisco was just the beginning. You kept going - Mexico, Canada, back across the country. The bus finally died in 1976. You bought another one. They say if you're still searching, you haven't found it yet. They're wrong. The road IS what you found. ğŸš

You stayed in San Francisco for a few years, then moved back east. Got a job, settled down. But every few years, you rent an RV and hit the road again. The spirit never really left you - it just learned to coexist with reality. âœŒï¸

The trip was harder than you expected. But you made it. Years later, you realize it wasn't about the destination - it was about proving to yourself that you could do hard things. The bus is gone, but the lesson remains. ğŸŒ…

You made it to San Francisco. The music festival was everything you hoped for and nothing like you expected. Life went on. But sometimes, when you hear a certain song, you're back in that VW bus, wind in your hair, whole life ahead of you. Those were the days. ğŸŒ»
